title: Is it true that Indo-Europeans were butchered by Turkic and Mongol tribes in Central Asia many years ago? - Quora

response.answer_text: Butchered would not be the correct word. The IE languages spoken in Central Asia and Siberia were gradually replaced by Turkic languages from the east. Historical and archaeological evidence indicates that Central Asia and Southern Siberia had been inhabited by Indo-European (specifically Indo-Iranian ) ethnic groups from c. 2000 BC to early centuries AD. This occupation was the result of the Sintashta- Andronovo expansion c. 2100 - 1500 BC out of the Pontic-Caspian steppes  Languages spoken across Eurasia in the first millennium BC However by the time the Scythians migrated west to Eastern Europe, substantial mixing with non IE populations seems to have taken place. During the period of the Great Migrations (300 - 500 AD), Turkic tribes from the Eastern steppes moved west, displacing the earlier Iranian inhabitants- Scythians and Sarmatians. This is the event that seems to have kick-started the Barbarian invasions of Europe and Southern Asia that destroyed the Western Roman Empire and ravaged many others. After this, the region of Inner Asia continued to be occupied by the Turkic tribes and they even gradually expanded westwards and southwards, founding the Ottoman Empire of Turkey and various Muslim kingdoms of the Middle East and India. The Iranian languages spoken in Central Asia (with the exception of Tajik still spoken in the Pamir highlands) were replaced by Turkic languages.  So the IE population of Central Asia was largely replaced by Turks though their genetic legacy still appears in the region.
